author: {'steamid': '76561199069512667', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2369, 'playtime_at_review': 5759, 'last_played': 1712370234}
review:
[h1] ğŸŒ±ğŸ’ğŸ¡ğŸŒ¦ï¸ğŸ¥• ğŸ¥¬ğŸª´ğŸ¥— [/h1]

My initial encounter with â€œOobletsâ€ dates back to 2020, the year in which it was primarily launched as an early-access farming simulator. Originally, I stumbled upon the game on Epic Games inasmuch as it hadn't been released on Steam; which, much to the fandom disappointmentâ€”myself includedâ€”, so remained for three more years. I am far from being impartial, since I am quite keen on the genre in question and have had rather pleasant previous experiences playing Ooblets. It had an indisputable positive, soothing and heart-warming impact on my personal life, and I dare to say that this reverberated to countless other players, notably so during such an astoundingly obscure and somber periodâ€”if not the most of all over the last two decadesâ€”for humanity.
I, for one, had been highly anticipating the arrival of this game on this platform and I am much content with all the further improvements the developers brought into play. 
The storyline is now much richer and cemented compared to the its first version. The side quests and regions to explore have been expanded, matured and polished. All in all, I am satisfied with how the game turned out to be in these more or less three years of development. A true labour of love, as you surely will witness yourself if you join the game's Discord server. 
Just bear in mind that Ooblets never aimed at being profound or story-rich. It is what promotes itself to be: simple, cute, casual and relaxing. [strike]And oftentimes quite silly also, but in the best of ways.[/strike] This piece holds a special place in my heart (â‰§â—¡â‰¦) â™¡ 

[u] [b] For the other Ooblet-lovers out there: what's your favourite Ooblet? [/b] [/u]
As of now, mine is the gleamy version of Dooziedug.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046902881', 'num_games_owned': 1047, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 1537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 92, 'playtime_at_review': 1537, 'last_played': 1711853129}
review:
Everything about this game is messy. 

The lack of quality of life features in this games made it so I didn't even bother finishing the game once the last steam achievement popped.

Whose idea was it to create a farming / creature collector game and then not even making there an easy storage or sorting feature for them? The houses to upgrade and store the critters is cute at first but.. when you realize they don't get bigger, area wise, with upgrading. So even with a full house of critters they only farm and clean right around them meaning you need to build as many houses as you possible can if you want to have all the critters.

Didn't even bother doing something akin to a pokedex as these games normally do, instead giving us a wildlife area where we can "set them free" (which also isn't anywhere close to your home)

I didn't mind the dance battles much, I enjoyed they were turn based. It fit the relaxing theme. Until you got to the area where you needed to get the number 1 highscore on a bunch of arcade games or you couldn't progress. There went the relaxation! I even had to ask my husband to help clear them. 

And did I mention it was messy? Tons of people running around. Tons of critters. Tons of garbage in town that respawn every day. Tons of "fun" gadgets that doesn't so anything other than be "fun" and you cannot even sell them or delete them so you end up having to just chuk them away into a storage box and forget about it.

review: Game felt super simple at first, turns out it starts out very slow on purpose to not overwhelm you with mechanics, that is until you reach the 2-hour mark then things become interesting! The more you play, the more you unlock, the more interesting the game becomes. I wasn't sure I was gonna like this when I started playing but now it's becoming one of my favorite comfort games. I hope they continue to add new stuff and soundtracks (they are lacking a bit in combat) in the future!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012193199', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2126, 'last_played': 1697582780}
review:
I played like 20 more hours of this after I stopped enjoying it, damn completionism. 

Bad: The game just feels shallow and tedious in all of its mechanics - combat feels like a chore, there's no complexity to it, only strategizing you can do is pick which ooblets join the fight, but the winning strategy is just going all damage, and the debuffs you can do don't feel like they affect the AI opponent at all (if there's more than one ooblet in the fight, stunning one or two almost never matters). The musical aspect feels underexplored. Running a shop is extremely tedious, super slow, with NPCs taking ages to decide on something.

Good: The aesthetics and the vibes of the game are absolutely amazing, There's somewhat of a story that drives you to progess with a simplistic anti-capitalist message in there too, which is cute. Ooblets helping you farm is a cool take at farm automation. 

If you don't care about completing the game, play for under an hour per session, and don't think about the combat too much,  this could be an enjoyable experience.

review:
Things I've learned that should be more apparent.
 - Use Coops to manage your Crops.
 - Plenny Deliveries are the best source of income.
 - Clubhouses have overpowered one time use cards.
 - Barn dances are excellent Wishies.
 - Game starts out slow then becomes a serious banger.

author: {'steamid': '76561199576303249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1395, 'last_played': 1710162553}
review:
I love love this game, I collect tiny babies, solve mysteries and enjoy the goofy vibes, that's my task list but there's so much to do, you can decorate your house, max out all friendships, find treasures in people's houses, explore the different towns, dance your way into better outfits.

Here are a list of games that if you like you'll like ooblets:
Animal crossing
Stardew Valley
Pokemon
Minecraft
Any Coolmath game

I laughed a lot playing this game and overall the aesthetic makes me so happy! I got it on sale but after playing would have happily played full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019142604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3106, 'last_played': 1710892886}
review: Fantastic game. I got it on sale and went in pretty much blind. It's a weird jungle juice blend of farming sim, creature collector,  and card game. The art style, story, and characters are charming and hilarious. The Ooblets are all adorable, and while some are definitely better than others in a dance battle, having higher/lower tier creatures in a creature collector game is nothing new and you aren't really denied having the ones you enjoy for the sake of it. I enjoy the added variety of uncommon/gleamy ooblets and the ridiculous customization. If I had to make requests it would be for more possibility to make little sanctuaries/play spaces for your ooblets. They work hard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025658024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 1415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1711083853}
review:
Most important points: yes, you can pet the Ooblets, AND dress them up in funny accessories, AND put them in little cars.

Ooblets is a pretty good game so far. It's also funny to me because it's the second time in a week I've picked up a "Pokemon clone" game that... is not a Pokemon clone.

If I had to compare Ooblets to an existing game, I would actually go with Animal Crossing: New Horizons. NH, specifically due to how the game starts. Both games have a sleepy kind of pacing that's trying to remind the player that you don't have to grind every minute of every day. As far as I can tell, days of the week in this game exist mainly to plan out Dance Barn tournaments. Nothing is on a timer. You [i]can't[/i] get everything done in one day and honestly, once I managed to internalize that, I started having a much better experience.

Ooblets does have 'mons that you can raise and battle, and recolor+sparkly versions (catch-em-all does pay off, literally, but it's not on a crunch). Until you open the Dance Barn, you might end up going a day or two with no 'battles' at all. The battle system is simple in a good way, and the individual strength of your Ooblets is less crucial than strategy skills. Knowing what your opponent can do and how to counter it can help, but nothing feels insurmountable even when I lose.

One thing I find super neat is the way challenging wild Ooblets work - you need to pay a toll, and each Ooblet type has a different price. The price is the same across varients, however - so if you've gotten some Frubtose, you might find yourself waiting to see if tomorrow will have an Unusual or even Gleamy Clickyclaws available. Each game day starts with a report of what Ooblets are available and where, and you can check your bestiary at any time outside of battle to see what each one needs (provided you've encountered them before). This lets the player strategize if you aren't at the point where whatever resource is easy to get, yet.

The game has some mechanical jankiness at times, especially oversight (ie trying to check that Ooblet report or see what Hankerbot told you), but overall the game lacks urgency, so if even failing doesn't sting like it might in a game where that has more major drawbacks. 

The farming system is pretty interesting, and there's friendships, quests, and a wilderness area to develop. You can dress up your character and get new hair and new hair colors (not sure if it's possible to change name or skin tone fwiw). You can 3D print figurines of Ooblets you've found. The fishing minigame is painless and always pays out to some extent. Overall, it's a very enjoyable experience to just pop in for an in-game day or two. Plus, you can save anywhere, not just by sleeping.

One thing to note is the game is relentlessly whimsical, in the way that will either drive you up the wall or renovate your entire vocabulary (or both). If that's not your thing, this may not be the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198851035955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3172, 'last_played': 1709432490}
review: This game encompasses everything I love... farming, shop keeping, card strategy,  collecting, cute characters, friendship building, adventuring, DRAMA, great on Steam Deck, decorating... and more. My ONLY gripe is that there are not achievements for "collecting all Ooblets" or "make every food recipe" or "max out all friendships"... all of the achievements were too easy which gave me less motivation to continue... if that makes sense. Love you OOBLETS thank youuuuu

author: {'steamid': '76561198282702067', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1866, 'last_played': 1709097426}
review: Cozy af

author: {'steamid': '76561198310613455', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1201, 'last_played': 1709011988}
review: Do not get this game. This game tries far too hard to appeal to an audience that no longer exists ie 2012 "I'm quirky cuz I like adventure time" tumblr girl. Incredibly forced writing. Extremely repetitive and agonizingly slow. And the last area has the gall to throw 3 extended fetch quest missions at you in a row, at which point, I quit. The music, the animations, the art style, is all so very frustrating and lacks so much of the charm I was expecting from this game. I gave it a fair shot, and I wouldn't even buy it on sale if I knew what this game was actually like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042248553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5561, 'last_played': 1708702902}
review: I bought this game on the Epic Game Store when it was first released in early access because I didn't want to have to wait to play it. Then I played the heck out of it on Steam to get all the achievements and collect literally every variant of every thing I can get. Now I'm thinking about buying it again on Switch to 100% it a third time. This game has it all and I cant get enough, I'd literally kill someone for an Ooblets 2. Buy this game if you love creature collectors, the visuals, or good silly fun. Do not buy this game if you respect your time. I've already spent 92 hours on my SECOND play-through and I'm still chugging lmao... somebody help me

author: {'steamid': '76561198035935978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1905, 'last_played': 1710631964}
review:
"It's incredible. It's a masterpiece. It's so stupid." - how I described this game to my partner

This game is a mash up of Stardew Valley and Pokemon. But with dance battles. And much sillier. But the thing that delighted me the most is that there actually started to be a compelling, oddly serious story line partway in. That's all I'll say to avoid spoilers. And that mash up of interesting plot in such a silly game really tickled me and cemented it as a game I love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190827799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2052, 'last_played': 1710982372}
review:
This game is exceptionally well-made, fun, and unique. I usually don't like character driven stories much, but the story here is well written, and the characters are anything but dull. My only suggestions is to expand the game, as it has so much more potential than being a single player-indie farming game. I have a few things I'd like to see with the development of this game. 

1. MORE OOBLETS! MORE LANDS!
we love Ooblets, they are cute and stupid, and follow us. We need more, and more lands to explore. 

2. OPEN WORLD, MULTIPLAYER

This game is somewhat similar to open world Pokemon games by the way you accumulate Ooblets and find them in different areas. However, it is much more humane and ethical than Pokemon, as you "dance battle" Ooblets using cards, defeat the Ooblet in dance, and earn a seed. Imagine an open world, where you can find Ooblets in less limited terrains. And in the case that its multiplayer too, it would be awesome to play with other players, dance battle Ooblets for rewards (kinda like the barn but with real players) and earn prizes! 

3. MORE STORY!
I want to know what happens next in Badgetown. Definitely more could be expanded here as there's so much potential and character building going on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040622674', 'num_games_owned': 715, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 2027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2027, 'last_played': 1708495333}
review: Overall quite a fun game. However, it feels kind of rough around the edges. Some of the models are kind of shoddy, completion rewards are absolutely disappointing and game progression feels kind of unbalanced. I would recommend playing it, because it's still quite a fun combination of pokemon and stardew valley. However, I would absolutely advise against 100% completing it, as most completion rewards are simply random loot drops.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998511508', 'num_games_owned': 516, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1710026820}
review:
TL;DR: I'd say it's definitely worth a look if you like slower-paced and more cutesy style games, which I do! :D

My thoughts: It has a strangely slow intro and it can be a little hard to know exactly what is going on and what you need to do. Once you are an hour in though, you really start to get into a good rhythm (heh) and it will all click. The strange way everything is presented really annoyed me the first time I played it but it definitely grows on you and it is endearing to say the very least!

The game runs really well, even on my Steam Deck and it's very much a game suited to the tuck up in bed and play before going to sleep style of game as if you play it as I have, on my main PC, you might get a little carried away and end up losing three hours to it... I mean I am not complaining but man, this game can be addictive as heck!

So, here are my thoughts:

Positives:
+ Game looks awesome and the art style is very unique!
+ It runs beautifully on my Steam Deck!
+ The dancing and card style battling is both hilarious and fun.
+ The sound is excellent! The music is top notch and the ambient sounds are also great.
+ There seems to be a nice variety of areas and other quests/characters to meet.

Negatives:

- The way each character talks might grate on some folks' nerves.
- It doesn't seem to run at anything higher than 60 FPS which on my main PC, is a little annoying as it can, and does, cause stuttering.

Overall thoughts: This game is really neat! It blends Animal Crossing with PokÃ©mon in a very unique way and I really like it. It's a very interesting experience and so far, I'm really enjoying it! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198048913108', 'num_games_owned': 577, 'num_reviews': 312, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1703369804}
review:
This review is all about the controversy (sorry in advance for hijacking the review system to do this). Please skip this if you can enjoy the game solely w/o looking at "the story behind the curtain." I'm really glad for you. In fact, a part of me wanna [i]unlearn[/i] the drama and just enjoy the game too!

And if you decide to continue, maybe you might wanna read the official statement from the developer in "We did the thing" [1] and "Regarding whatâ€™s been happening" [2] first, to avoid my bias.

TL;DR: it's the classic question: "can we support the art but not the artist?", which, in this case the artist's behavior quite outweighs the art.

---

The controversy took place in 2019 when Ooblets signed a time-exclusive deal with Epic, and the dev announce it in a "tongue-in-cheek" tone [1]. While you can communicate a non-serious and/or positive update (e.g., holiday patch) with a relax/joke tone, communicating bad news is already dangerous in itself. The least you can do is make it formal (and that's not even guaranteed you'll avoid the backlash). So why still going on with the troll-baiting style, which almost ensure a disaster?

Ideally, that announcement should be short, to the point, empathizing, apologizing, and reassuring. Something like "Due to our financial status, we decided to take Epic's deal, resulting in a one-year time-exclusive on Epic Store. We will be happy to see your support on Epic Store when the game is out. However, we do understand that some players are unable to switch stores; thus, we apologize for this inconvenience. Rest assured that our intention is to publish the game on every storefront, and we will make that happen as soon as possible."

I'm aware that paraphrasing the statement won't make the backlash vanished (since there are [i]a lot[/i] of Epic haters). But at least, keeping it short means there'll be less chance to upset/offend someone with miscellaneous out-of-topic chitchatting, like suggesting people vent out the anger on the climate change instead.

For me, I'm not ok with [1] in the part the dev assume everyone play Fortnite. Well, here I am, someone who never plays Fortnite because of motion sickness. So I'm really wonder why the dev make such strong claim over a diverse group of people (especially when Ooblets has non-overlap target group with Fortnite...) Nonetheless, I saw the whole announcement as a bad-taste joke which I can tolerate. And, honestly, if I were in their position, I'd take the deal too.

I also understand that [1] meant to be communication only with their supporters. What I don't understand is why it's a public post? Especially when the dev seems fully aware that the statement will definitely upset the public: "Okay, so we did the thing! The thing people get angry about. But maybe don't get angry about it?" [3].

Of course, after the announcement, the dev got backlash. I'm not surprised. What surprised me was that the dev themselves choose to participate in this flame war. Well, I'm aware many screenshots are fake (like the Holocaust or the Malaysian's dad). But would those fake screenshots look [i]convincing[/i] and spread fast like fire if the dev choose their words wisely (or just stayed silent)? Not to mention that the real replies from the dev, although taken out of context, are still terrible way to talk to another [i]person[/i], regardless of being their customer or not.

And I'm also aware that, on the other end, there are people who send rape/death threats, which I condemn too. I condemn them to a greater degree than the poorly communication from the developer. Basically, no one should be sending/receiving such threat.

I know the frustration being on the receiving end --- been there too. We are human beings with emotions and biases. We get angry when someone crosses the line, insulting us. That prompts us to fight back, luring us to think that we have all the rights to return the violence, right?

But you can't fight fire with fire, especially when you are the one in the spotlight. You have everything to lose. Your reputation. Your customers. Everything. And what will the public anonymous lose? None. So why engage in this fight?

Well, I believe that the dev already learned it the hard way, as seen in the aftermath write-up [2].

However, there's an important point that's been overlooked in [2]: when you decide to fight in the public, you risk making collateral damages to bystanders, risk turning strangers into enemies.

And the damage has been done.

The least the dev can do is release an official apology. But no, [2] is just recap on what happened. Say thanks to their supporters. Never a sorry. (Go ahead if you gonna call it an apology. There's a huge gap between "It was a stupid miscalculation on my part." and "I say means thing to people, sorry." --- especially when the first one was followed by "I recognize that none of this post equates to an apology in any way that a lot of the mob is trying to obtain, and that's by design. While some of what I've said was definitely bad for PR, I stand behind it.")

Sigh...

This world is not black and white. Not everyone outside of your circle is going to be your enemy. There are people who are not taking side too. There are even people who never heard your game before. And when these people decide to learn more about the game, will they gonna hear about the cute-relaxing gameplay, or the louadspeaking drama which turning them away.

The game has been out for a while, even surpassing the Winter Sale phase. The reviews almost land on the "Overwhelmingly Positive" zone. But the total number of reviews was not yet exceed 1k! Compared to other indies in the same spectrum, I'd say Ooblets could achieve a number of reviews (and sales figures) larger than this by a magnitude or two. (To get into perspective: Stardew Valley has 500k reviews, Hades 200k, Celeste 70k.) And that's is a missed opportunity, which I strongly doubt that the game would be more successful if it resolved the controversy better. (See No Man's Sky for how to comeback from the controversy. And IIRC, Hades was once Epic time-exclusive too, but still loved by players [i]everywhere[/i].)

We are human after all. We made mistakes out of our stupidities. Everyone does that at some points in their life. Of course, no one should be punished forever, but it takes effort to ensure this kind of mistake won't happen again (or at least won't happen easily). While an apology won't help resolve every kind of mistake, saying a sincere sorry is a sign that [i]we[/i] realize we are a part of the problem, and we're willing to fix it. (Besides, saying sorry literally costs nothing, except, maybe, one's ego.)

I guess people won't forgive the developer easily when they don't even bother considering saying sorry?

(Last but not least, it's seems like the dev already achieved the "magnet" aspect they sought for, only that it didn't quite attract customers to Epic Store [5], but attracted the same kind of people to their community instead. Either the haters who're gonna attack the game forever, or the overprotective followers who're gonna defend their dev [i]no matter what[/i]. Especially Tim Sweeney, who fans the flame, instead of helping resolve the conflict [4]. All of them share the same qualities of being impulsive, unapologetic, overconfident, and trolling. Maybe this is the classic "you reap what you sow" & "birds of a feather flock together", huh?)

Sorry for a lengthy post, which has nothing to do with the game at all. And thanks for a great case study on how [i]NOT[/i] to do a PR.

---

[1]: We did the thing, https://ooblets.com/2019/07/we-did-the-thing/
[2]: Regarding whatâ€™s been happening, https://medium.com/@perplamps/3af0f27d863c
[3]: Ooblets's tweet, https://twitter.com/ooblets/status/1156958973016174592
[4]: Tim Sweeney's tweet, https://twitter.com/TimSweeneyEpic/status/1157561293995462657
[5]: The Verge's news, https://www.theverge.com/2023/11/6/23949372/

author: {'steamid': '76561198025207810', 'num_games_owned': 845, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1705826277}
review:
I wish I could give a neutral review. Ooblets is a charming game with great visuals -- unfortunately most of everything else about it is...alright. Outside of combat, the gameplay boils down to collecting items (whether by growing it or foraging it) and turning them in. That's it, that's the gameplay. Other features in the game such as fishing and townie relationships feel like their presence is an obligation more than something with any depth or passion behind it.

It's very clear this was made on a small budget and I think in some ways it's impressive what they pulled off, but in others I think it really made me yearn for something with more depth. The combat is mindlessly easy. I only lost 2 fights in my first 10 hours. Just spam hype cards at the beginning of combat, then point cards. That's all you need to know to win 95% of encounters for the game. And another thing, as a lot of other reviewers mention, requiring 3 X resources in your inventory in order to fight/collect new Ooblets in the wild is lame and is clearly a way to shoe-horn in the crafting/farming system you are already constantly doing to progress in the game.

I don't mean to sound overly negative about the game, it's charming and some people will really dig what it is. But it hurts all the more because I feel like this was close to being a great game instead of an okay fetching-items-to-progress-the-story-simulator. I'd soft recommend it at $15-$20 because it's still fun, but nothing to write home about and not *that* much variety of content for $30.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039821823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 5009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4987, 'last_played': 1705915230}
review:
I like this game. I have played it for 83.1 hours and have all 27 achievements. It's graphically pretty.

Having your Ooblets be able to get driver's licenses and drive around in vehicles at max level is absolutely adorable, and watching the occasional wild Ooblet slamming into things in a tiny car is great.

I have laughed several times at the NPC dialogue and references, so the humor is generally to my liking, and I do find the game cute in the silly way it names objects. I don't particularly care for the instances of toilet humor in the game. There are several things that are referred to as "tooting," plants named after farts, and the Ooblets audibly fart out seeds, which I find kind of gross and not relaxing.

There are several things in-game that are not explained which you have to use a search engine to try and find answers to. These include: What do Ooblet levels do? What do your own personal levels do? Are Gleamy Ooblets better stat-wise than other rarities? I still haven't been able to find an answer to the second and third ones.

This game lacks depth compared to similar farming/RP-type games because your relationships with the NPCs remain very surface level, and it feels like you're just repetitively grinding small talk with the NPCs in the town on a daily basis. You don't really establish a bond with and a sense of pride at improving the town like you do in Stardew Valley. 

The end of the game comes quite confusingly and I found it somewhat unsatisfying. I saw no reason to play anymore after the last quest. The game did not offer any more achievements or goals to pursue, so getting more currency or collecting more rare Ooblets was pointless.

If there were some more features added onto the game it could feel less grindy:

I wish there was an option to establish a deeper relationship with the NPCs, something that would allow you to choose someone to move onto your farm with you. I always enjoy the option to romance in these types of games, or to have a roommate. It feels a bit lonely all by myself with my trail of Ooblets on my farm.

There are some quality of life improvements that would make this game friendlier towards people who have progressed further. We should be able to move buildings on the farm without stripping them of their Ooblets, which leads to a micromanaging disaster, especially if you don't have space for them to be stored. You can't sort/filter your Ooblets by what building they are assigned to, or even in alphabetical order. I have 112+ Ooblets now and it's really, really annoying to try and find them when I am swapping them between myself and my farm. Being able to name your chests would help, as well as being able to split stacks of items. Farm buildings should show what and how many seeds are stored without having to go through a cutscene to look into each of them.

I wish fishing was more than just spending a long time getting bait and pressing a fish button and receiving one dispensed piece of randomized loot. If there was a mini-game option that gave greater rewards, that would provide more allure.

I wish your Ooblets' costumes didn't go invisible when they were assigned to farm buildings, and their designs weren't hidden underneath straw hats.

I wish there was more variety in music and dances. Hearing and watching the same thing over and over again in dance battles gets repetitive.

I wish that your character's eyebrows would match your hair color as you change it. They just stay a clashing color all the time.

I did run into a few bugs as a PC user with a keyboard and mouse. There are some parts of the game that don't support WASD movement, and some parts that are buggy, like the 3D printer which won't allow you to scroll down with the keyboard. Often a middle card in dance battles cannot be selected with the keyboard and you have to use the mouse to select it. Somehow I ended up frozen to a computer screen in the game and had to force quit the game to reload it.

I recommend the game, as it does a good job of keeping you playing despite being somewhat grindy and repetitive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095394949', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 3168, 'last_played': 1711926737}
review: I have now played through this game 3 times, once on Switch, Epic and now Steam. I cannot stress how lovely this game is. The Pokemon collectathon scratches my brain like no other and the card based dance mechanics are a delight. The aesthetics  of the game are too cute and not too pushy like many games who try too hard to lean into the cuteness aspect. The story is just awesome and silly as well and has some very fun nods to some fun social commentary that I can't get enough of. This quickly became one of my favorite games and if you're considering buying it I can't recommend it enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092134320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1705113725}
review:
Really repetitive and bland to be honest which is insanely disappointing. Been waiting for this game for years and while I can tell the devs put a lot of work and heart into the game there's just really not a lot of meet to it. From what I understood in the marketing, it was supposed to be equal parts: 
Stardew Valley: farming and meeting interesting characters and getting involved in their stories. 
And another equal part Pokemon: meeting and collecting monsters, mastering the battle system (dancing) 
and that these two halves would make a holistically unique game.
It's in fact just less involved Stardew. There's a bad battle mechanic you do sometimes.
There's also monsters, I guess. Cool.
The vibe gets grating and obnoxious after a while. Very wannabe adventure time and regular show with the made up vernacular and low self esteem teen comedy. I don't know maybe I'm just too old to gel with it. 
The NPCs are all bland and boring, with barely any ways to interact with them. The farming is weirdly really hard to make money with? It feels like no matter what you're doing you're barely making end's meet. 
Like dude come on I have to collect resources to battle monsters? And it doesn't tell me how to get the item I need to battle the monsters? There's no way to track what monsters need what food from the ooblet manual in the pause menu? There are plenty of other people, including club leaders that are basically gym leaders, but I can't battle any of them? I can't see what teams they make and strategies there are and learn about their personalities through battling? You couldn't put tool tips to explain the mechanics or what they mean? I can't even edit my deck, it's just a collection of really terrible base cards and whatever I get through leveling? Come on.
I was looking for something that would let me pick and choose what I wanted to do so I could have fun with the game that I bought. Not a time-locked chore sim.
One of the regular things that you do in the game is mash A to collect a pile of cans to feed into a machine that takes MINUTES to make bait so you can watch the same animation and get junk from the ocean. Almost every thing you do throughout the day is pretty much exactly that. They're not fun and engaging, but they're things you HAVE to do to progress. They're not suggestions, they're not "things you can do if you're out of things to do/need ideas on what to do today." They're required to get any sort of economy going. 
It's disappointing, tedious, and, at times, annoying. 
Sorry, Glumberland. I wish you luck on your next game. Like I said you guys are clearly passionate and had a vision and I respect that. Maybe with some polish this could be a really special game for the right kind of people. But I don't think I'll ever be that kind of person. I'm all set with this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198287069604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 838, 'last_played': 1707675812}
review:
Things I love about ooblets:
1.  SO many lil guys.  A game for lil guy fans.  And you can dress them up. And they can drive vehicles.  What's not to like? 
2.  The game is very forgiving about time. There's no incentive to play daily, but at your own pace!  (Other than holiday events I guess.)  So if you're away for a few days due to life it'll open right where you save.  Plus, you can save in the middle of the day too!
3.  No weirdly hard fishing mini game compared to the rest of the gameplay.
4.  Fairly fleshed out NPCS, despite the amount of characters.  And no friendship decay (that I've spotted).  
5.  Still getting updates!  

Things that annoy me a bit about ooblets:
1.  You can't really customize the deck that you build, but rather the ooblets that you choose are the way you customize your deck.  As someone who is a fan of deck based games this is something I had to get over.
2.  The dance battles can be repetitive. 
3.  Sometimes the changes of nouns (ei, caroot instead of carrot) can be funny, but some can feel childlike in like, a bad way. 
4.  A game like this would 100% be a great place for modders (lots of customization options, low poly models), but mods aren't supported.  

If you like casual silly games with card 'combat', lots of fetch quests, and collecting creatures, this is a game you might want to check out.  I've been listening to an audiobook while playing and it's been a great time.

I can easily play this game for hours at a time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079096334', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1456, 'last_played': 1704946683}
review: Pokemon meets Animal Crossing meets Stardew Valley with dance battles. Like the fever dream of a madman in all the best ways. I 100% completed the achievements and beat the main story line and there are still things I could go back and do such as collecting all the Ooblets and continue farming and decorating my house. Honestly an incredibly fun time. There are some redundant tasks and some things seem to have harder goals for the sole purpose of extending the gameplay but overall I didnâ€™t feel it detracted from my enjoyment at all. Hard to put down once I picked it up. 100% recommend. Played and completed entirely on the Steam Deck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198796789610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4010, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3119, 'last_played': 1705452905}
review: I enjoy the pacing of this game, and the art style. The music grows on you, and may very well get stuck in your head. Of call cozy games I've played, I recommend this one highly and maybe more than any other. Simply because it doesn't require a huge investment of time where you feel totally helpless and then start gaining ground. There's always something to do, and there's a fun advancement. Don't rush to do anything too fast. I'm on my second playthrough after putting it down for about a year and loving it much more this time.

author: {'steamid': '76561199586153631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1211, 'last_played': 1704082704}

author: {'steamid': '76561199394147992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6674, 'last_played': 1705010485}
review:
Cute game, love collecting Ooblets.  I'm so happy that a farming sim hasn't gone the way of so many others with overly graphic battle/combat.  Dance battles?  I'm here for them!

Solid 8/10.

I had to take points off for the visuals.  It's near to impossible to see anything when it's snowing or raining and as someone who wears glasses?  It can give me a headache at times straining and struggling to see.

Also, points were removed for how short the story is.  It was over so quickly that I've already completed a second play through!

Those two points are not game breaking though and everything else that is positive about this happy little game more than makes up for them.  It is a farming game, so having to collect/grow things to do dance battles or complete tasks is to be expected.  Some of the items are harder to obtain than others and that is what makes it challenging and adds longevity to the game.  

I hope the developers have updates planned!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994977722', 'num_games_owned': 1818, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1861, 'last_played': 1704609351}
review:
Good:
- story is good
- resource balance is good

Bad:
- battle AI is nonexistent, both for "wild" battles and "versus" battles
- parts of the game feel unfinished, locations exist solely for story and to provide resources for player, there's nothing interesting there after you done the story part and only reason to visit them is to collect resources
- everything, EVERYTHING is tied to farming and gathering. You want to battle wild monsters? They require items to even begin battle, items obtained through farming (and then crafting) in 90% cases, want to improve and automate your farm? Better get back to farming and foraging. There's literally no other activity besides farming and gathering. Your farm is full and you're waiting for crops to grow? Better till a piece of land over and over so that you can nap/sleep to skip a day, or visit all other locations to see if resources respawned

Ugly:
- visual design and sound design sucks the soul out of me
- everything is a chore
- even minigames suck the soul out of me
- NPCs are useless, Friendship system is meaningless, it just gives resources. All NPCs are pretty much cardboard cutouts, stupid, boring, insufferable or all of the above.

TL;DR: Chore simulator the game, if you like doing chores it's for you. Or if you like the style of the game. I don't. This game made me feel like going back to AC:NL and smashing money rocks every day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053980174', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1200, 'last_played': 1704680445}
review: This game does what it sets out to do: a farming sim with collectible creatures in a quirky world.  Doesn't reinvent either genre nor does it really try anything new.  I give it a solid 7/10.  Do what I did and wait for a sale on this game; imo, it's not worth $30.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152273593', 'num_games_owned': 46, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1689, 'last_played': 1706289646}
review:
I've actually played the game for over 200 hours, counting the time I spent playing on the Epic Games Store version during early access. I moved my save files over to steam recently.

This is a delightfully cozy creature collector; The world feels so adorable and quirky with lovable characters and appealing designs. The main story is fun to go through and doesn't take very long, and has a nice anti-capitalist message that I appreciate. Despite it's short story, It's something come back to from time to time when I just want to relax and exist in a world that feels like it was built with neurodivergency as the norm. If you're looking for a chill game with dancing, farming, and exploration, then this is a no-brainer.

author: {'steamid': '76561199137639872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1467, 'last_played': 1704223186}
review:
For the first 30 minutes, I thought I was going to hate this.  The music is jarring, the dialogue is beyond stupid, but once you get past the tutorial the actual gameplay is decent.  The card based battles are good, the farming is laid back, aside from optional daily quests, most quests are not time-sensitive, you can do them whenever you feel like it or just farm and collect poke---er, "ooblets."  

The music stays obnoxious, but that's what the mute button and audiobooks are for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966346481', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2144, 'last_played': 1704106826}
review:
A very quirky, relaxing game where creature-collector meets life-sim. Every NPC and Ooblet has a unique personality, that you fall in love with quickly. The music and vibes throughout the whole experience definitely lifted my mood throughout the day. It's a great cozy game, and great if you want to just turn your brain off and not think too hard.

The battle system is very simple, but structured in a very nice way. It doesn't have too much depth to it, which could be either a positive or negative, depending on what you're looking for. The barn dances mix things up a little bit in difficulty, but most of the time, you'll find yourself just clicking the same cards without any regard to what the opponent is doing.

The story is good, and I definitely got pulled into it a bit near the ending, but it too lacks a bit of depth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030896208', 'num_games_owned': 634, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 4273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4232, 'last_played': 1704073316}
review:
Extremely addictive for the collectors out there. Kinda like Harvest Moon and Pokemon had a child in the world of Adventure Time. For all its addictive qualities, the drawbacks are just as severe. Balance was apparently the farthest thing from anyone's mind when creating this game. I had to search the internet for some game concepts because there was no in-game explanations (hype for example). Some resources are way too plentiful, others are scarce, but not in balance with their demand/usage. And too many currencies. It can make your head spin.

Good if you're looking for a game to fill those niches for collecting or a laid back farming sim experience. The rough edges will shine through eventually, though.

review: I had this game for Christmas and haven't come off it yet, it's addictive.  The Ooblets are cute, love them.  The Oobs are all kind of quirky and in some cases downright sinister (looking at you Taffy, is it because you're clown, I think it is!) Thing is though I can't not like any of them and I love the fact they have to warm up to you before they start hanging out goodies or even asking for help.  Came here for the farming aspect, totally neglected that and danced the night away (in real time) with the Ooblets.  One of the best Christmas presents of the year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198258441241', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 797, 'last_played': 1705656332}
review:
I have never written any reviews before but I'm making one now purely for the sake of making suggestions.

So far, I enjoy the vibe of the game. It's very chill and reminiscent of Stardew Valley since you can farm, talk to NPCs and gain friendship with them, and collect things across the land while you explore. It's also a bit like Pokemon, but only the player can initiate having a battle with the wild Ooblets (if they have the required resources to do so).

My main cons so far about gameplay:
- Unable to set framerate (seems to be uncapped and varies between 144fps to 40fps depending on the area loaded)
- Chests cannot be placed outside your house. Player has to constantly go in and out of the house to grab things to craft at the furniture store.
- In Dance Battles, there's no descriptors for things like Fluster, Trepidation, etc. I had to manually go look them up on a fan wiki to see what those actually did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019026575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1703916317}
review: Super-Cool, Super Chill. Grow pets in your garden. Do battle with other trainers and their pets using a dance move deck of cards. Each  pet has different card attacks. I've only just begun and the battles so far are fun, cute and too easy.  Hoping the "dance offs" get more challenging with progression. If so, it will be pretty great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112875359', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 4349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4349, 'last_played': 1699410397}
review: I'm not going to pretend like it is not a bit cringe (it's got a lot of that weird terminally online older Gen Z, younger Millennial quirky Tumblr 2012 SUPERWHOLOCK humour) but the eyeroll adds to the charm for me. It's light and silly, it's fun to collect the ooblets, and once you figure out your battle strategy you'll feel so powerful lol. It feels like a slice of a time period, good for a little escape.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271930298', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1703538189}
review:
I had to refund this after half an hour of play time. The cutesy millennial speak and simlish speak threw me into a rage. I'm accustomed to indie games and their quirks but this was just so bad. The character customization was very lacking, there's like 4 different skin & hair tones, and a couple more hairstyles. The ooblets themselves don't have very unique or interesting designs. I'd describe this as Animal Crossing mixed with Pokemon, but missing the good parts of both. I think there's a lot that could be done to improve this game and make it worthwhile. For now, I wouldn't recommend it.

Only positive thing I'll say is that the ooblets having dance battles made me laugh a little.

author: {'steamid': '76561198842815927', 'num_games_owned': 26, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3067, 'last_played': 1704293607}

author: {'steamid': '76561198055203007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1704512930}
review:
Cutest game I've played in a long time and a solid competitor to Nintendo's Animal Crossing! If Animal Crossing, Pokemon, and Stardew Valley had a baby, this would be it! Defeat ooblet creatures in cute little dance battles to earn their seeds, which you can then plant in the ground to grow your own ooblet creatures. Some ooblets are rarer than others and have different colors. You can also dress them up in cute little accessories!

There is so much more i could say about this game. The dialogues are quirky and adorable. You can farm, fish, and decorate your house, shop and craft. This is the perfect game to represent to Cozy game genre. The only thing that would complete this game and make it perfect is if it had online co-op.  All in all, highly recommend this game and I can already tell I will be sinking hundreds of hours into this. ğŸ˜

review: This is probably one of my favorite games of all time, simply because of its versatility. You can play both casually and more seriously. I actually got this game the day my tonsils were removed because it looked entertaining but not too difficult for my post-operation brain to understand, and since then I've become hooked! The little ooblets are so stinkin cute, the story line is nice and casual but fun, and the strategy isnt too bad either. Definitely recommend, especially as a gift for someone younger, or anyone who loves cute things!!

author: {'steamid': '76561199583626885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2458, 'last_played': 1709357268}
review: Ooblets is such an addicting game. It has seriously kept me entertained and hooked for hours. The animation style is really cute; there's so many creatures to collect and quests to complete it'll certainly keep you busy. My only complaint is that once you finish the main story line there's not as much of a purpose to play. Of course it's fun trying to collect the rest of the ooblets, but that's definitely a slow and tedious task. However, you have a solid 30 some-odd hours of game time before you complete the story line. I just speed ran it in a few days lol.

author: {'steamid': '76561198398421396', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2647, 'last_played': 1698982398}
review: Words cannot describe how unimaginably satisfying it is to create a workforce exclusively consisting of minuscule mushroom men. Watching the spore filled sweat drip from their mushroom brows as they tirelessly turn my muz into flour. Seeing as they desperately attempt to learn English to try and muster the word "help" but realize I am the only human within earshot from our secluded farmhouse. Hearing them beg for a drivers license as they watch their superior brothers and sisters driving their brand new sports cars. It sure is a good day to be a farmer in the land of Oob.ğŸ˜‡

author: {'steamid': '76561198182625123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1703714714}
review:
I wasn't 100% sure about how I'd feel about this game with the initial idea that it's semi-like pokemon in a way. It also came across as being a little bit overwhelming due to the sheer number of Ooblets I've seen in trailers. After playing this for about a week, I'm not sure how I could've thought that. This is a cozy, slow game where you collect cute animals, farm, and play mini games. The dance battles are delightful and adorable. The dialogue and references to modern life are cute and comical. It's like a cute alternate reality, and I LOVE the vibes!

I'd recommend this for any age person that enjoys enchanting, calming game play. If you enjoy Stardew Valley, Animal Crossing, or any game in that vein, you'll likely enjoy this one too! I personally use games to distract myself when I need some calm in my life. If you're looking for something like that, this is perfect. There's not too much hand-holding and it's not too juvenile, so it's great even for experienced gamers and adults.

TL;DR:
Great game, very calming. If you like Stardew and Animal Crossing, then you'll probably enjoy this since it has elements of both.

Happy Gaming!

author: {'steamid': '76561198313822271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1697370601}

author: {'steamid': '76561198056780727', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5872, 'last_played': 1704008195}
review:
Ooblets is a very special game to me. Special in the fact that after a 1 year wait to get it on steam, Glumberland is still hard at work making a fantastic game even better. Is it good though? Well this is a tough question to answer but the reason is with all the fun activities, where do I start with?

I guess at its base it's a farming sim, the meat of the fruit and veggies is that you will be planting and watering a lot, kinda like other farming sims such as Stardew. The twist is that the second biggest aspect of your new farm life is that you must dance battle other plant/animal/robot monster things to get seeds to grow your own allies to get in even more dance battles! Shake it Followbabies!

Other notable aspects are doing tasks for the mayor to help develop Badgetown, the town you live in, and progress the game's story line. Travelling to lots of different locations. Talking to people all over the world and giving gifts to help develop friendships. Raising crops to sell and cook into tasty dishes. Daily dance tournaments that give exclusive rewards. And my favourite task of all, tracking down beautiful colourful "gleamys" (they are effectively shiny pokÃ©mon folks) and really taking to the dance floor with tracers and sparkles as I dance the night away! There's also fishing that has no mini game! You just put bait on the line, cast it away and you're always guaranteed to get something, wow!

If I haven't sold you on the ridiculous zany fun that is Ooblets by now, perhaps this is not the game for you. It is kinda a nichÃ© music card battler farming sim dance battle extravaganza. But if any of this sounds like it would appeal to you, I would heavily encourage you pick it up today and start your new life with your new Ooblet friends! <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198318727816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4576, 'last_played': 1701846336}
review:
The dance battle system is really boring after first few hours. It takes waaaaay too much time to complete even a very simple game with some normal ooblets. It's not necessary to give the other party who is not a REAL PERSON to demonstrate what card they use, then the dance move on their obblets, and finally the card's effect on the score. I almost fell asleep a few times during the dance battle though the music was loud. This really prevented me from collecting all the ooblets. Please give at least some options to fast forward this process. 
I really like this game though. Hope there would be more decorations, furniture, and details update. Absolutely cuteness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198242599416', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1905, 'last_played': 1703536756}
review:
I played through this on the switch first, and I was delighted to finally have it on PC. (I was unwilling to install the epic launcher just for this title, so I waited)

The only cons would be the lack of save data transfer from the switch, and the devs post about why they didn't come to steam at the OG launch. That passive aggressive commentary was enough that I actually stopped playing for awhile. I could respect going with epic for the money, but the attempt at joking about installing the launcher was instead frankly rude. After seeing some other comments on the discord and reddit, I came to the conclusion this was not their intended tone. 

It is not like anything I have ever played before, while also feeling familiar. Other reviews have made accurate comparisons to Animal Crossing, Pokemon, Stardew / while being nothing like those titles at the same time.

I bought it on PC to play back through after logging more than 400 in-game-days on switch. If you like the above mentioned games, you'll likely love this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169812165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1581, 'last_played': 1705363134}
review:
I've seen a lot of (valid) criticism surrounding what people call "cozy games." Games that you play at your own pace, often involve entirely low-stress encounters, and piggyback off of the 'cozy' aesthetic. I'd say that Ooblets fits under this category, but as a glowing example of what I WANT with this experience. Since I'm super autistic, I'm not skimping on the details. Here are the multiple factors that drive me to recommend this game to ANYONE:

1. The "cozy" aesthetic. Let me get one think clear, this game doesn't simply come off as 'cozy.' Describing it simply by that one term isn't fair to the energy the developers created. The game is weird, silly, charming, and much more. Of course any game with farming as a primary mechanic is going to feel cozy, but when little creatures sprout from seeds you planted, of course "cozy" isn't all you're getting.

2. Ooblets. The game is CALLED Ooblets, and for good reason. The creatures that you will encounter are called Ooblets, and let me tell you.. these little guys are so varied and charming. The creature design here is so charming, as they feel like if something you doodled on the side of your math notes was fleshed out and fully rendered. The ones here are already great, and judgeing by the consistent updates, I imagine more will be available. I am OBSESSED with these little guys, and I can guarentee you will be too!

3. Dance battles. This mechanic is one of my favorites. Are you ever playing Pokemon and feel bad that you have to hurt yours and another Pokemon to progress? Not here. If you encounter Ooblets out and about, you get them by making your ooblets DANCE OFF with them. I won't go into details with how the mechanics work since you'll figure it out when you play, but its FUN. And when you beat an ooblet, instead of catching it and taking it away from its pals, it gives you a seed that you can GROW ON YOUR FARM, and raise to be your very own. Basically mechanic good.

There's more I COULD say, but I'd rather people just get the game and explore. I'm not quite finished as I'm trying not to rush through the game, but it gives you a LOT to do, and all of it feels incredibly fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027903892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3465, 'last_played': 1701657738}
review: Ooblets is a cute farming game with dance battles. The game is similar to Stardew Valley without the cave exploration. It has a story but most of it is told right at the end and it doesn't really engage the other characters much. The clubs also don't seem to have a lot of utility. As a farming and home decorating game it's very very cute and fun to make money and buy furniture and clothes for yourself and your little Ooblets. The game sports a collection feature in the catching and growing of the ooblets and a management feature as the ooblets take over chores on the farm. All in all it's a super cute game.

author: {'steamid': '76561199061469203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1697550180}
review:
This game is fun and cute. You collect Ooblets through the means of dance battles. Family friendly game and great if you like games where you collect things, farming, item management, and decoration. It's such a vibrant, colourful game and I love the art style. I got this around Halloween and the town was kitted out in Halloween decorations so it seems like the devs put a lot of time and effort into seasonal updates.

You might not enjoy this game as much, however, if you like story rich games. Asides from quests and the basic premise of the game, there's not much story at all.  NPCs are a bit flat too. This was definitely a downside for me unfortunately and I got a bit bored after a while. However, if these things don't bother you, and you're more interested in collecting and exploring then you will most likely enjoy this game. It's one I will definitely go back to in time, and overall had a lot of fun playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148912249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1763, 'last_played': 1702864668}

author: {'steamid': '76561199020816660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7443, 'last_played': 1705394393}
review: I loved this game a lot, some points that I like are that I've always loved the concept of farming sims, but I could just never get into stardew valley as I felt the days were too short and there was too much to do. This game, however, hooked me from the get go. I am a huge pokemon fan so I love the ooblets, some strange cute little creatures, the first time I saw them. The story was delightfully whimsical for me and I really enjoyed the ending, just wish I could replay the final battles again.  I am a collector at heart so I spent a lot my time resetting for gleamies after finishing the story, and that is the part that gets tedious, but it's of my own volition. I really enjoyed the halloween update and am really looking forward to what future updates may bring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198204829091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1702375106}
review: It's fun but it's feeling like its kind of lacking in a way. If you're looking for a super story based game this game isn't it. There's really no connections with the characters or the ooblets and it's not as engaging as I had expected it to be. I feel as though it's more based on mainly collecting and farming and kind of accessorizing your character and your ooblets. The map starts out super small and it threw me off and also the fact that farming is what you rely on the most but it's difficult to make a good earning in the game. There needs to be more ways to earn money rather than having to sell things or do quests that still require you to collect crops or materials. The ways you can collect materials is also very limited as you run out of wood and rocks eventually and have no other way to obtain them as far as I can see from the amount of time I've played other than buying them. The drawing and ooblets are fun and the dancing is interesting but it's always the same thing and it slowly starts to be less engaging since it starts to feel more like a grind instead of having any strategic way of winning. I wouldn't say I hated the game completely but It was lacking more than it was entertaining and I would not say it would be worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126558508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 8900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 792, 'playtime_at_review': 5032, 'last_played': 1711939051}
review:
Excellent, super cute, relaxing game!
I remember adding this game to my Follow list when it was first announced. I waited years to play it, and it has MORE than exceeded my expectations!
It's so cute! A great way to de-stress after a long day at work and a terrible commute.
It's like Pokemon combined with Stardew Valley, and the adorable low-poly graphics of Donut County. Now add in the number of collectables from Katamari Damacy. There you have it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198015199624', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 12672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 17, 'playtime_at_review': 10652, 'last_played': 1711498645}
review:
Goofy and gentle, for me an extremely low-stress experience; as a Poke-Dew Crossing type, it's definitely low-pressure. Fishing has literally never been simpler or less stressful.  Art style is cute and fits the narrative quite well. I've finished the story and am still playing because I'm enjoying it.

Ooblet variety is good, I find cooking fun, and the silliness of crop types is delightful.

My one complaint for this game is the organization of the Ooblet page in your journal: I wish it it either grouped all the same oob together, or all the same types (common/unusual/gleamy or point-of-origin), so that finding the oobs you're trying to add to your team was a little less of a hassle, but alas

I have played this title exclusively on the steam deck and have been very happy with the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561199065790471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1707683971}
review: I've really been enjoying this game. It has cute and simple aesthetics and calming music. The cute ooblets are fun to collect, and there are so many. I've played for 8 hours so far and have done a lot, but there's so much more to explore. It's so sweet and peaceful. I look forward to buying new outfits and picking new hair color then browsing the furniture store. It's what life should be fr.

author: {'steamid': '76561198185966403', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1701223165}
review:
This is soooooo much better than other big names in farming sim this year!!

To begin with, it is truly relaxing and the mechanics are perfect.
I have tried other popular names like Coral Island and in most of these games I couldn't really relax because I'd never find ways to make proper amount of money and the controls of farming, like selecting the right square to water would be very tedious. I couldn't get past my frustration with those games.

With this game, I never even got frustrated. The fact that there is a separate farming mode in Ooblets makes it so much easier to control. There's a variety of tasks you can do if you want to make money in some other way as well! The game is humorous in ways you wouldn't expect and the ooblets are the cutest. I also really enjoy where the updates are heading, such as the addition of Ooblet Vehicles. It's sooo fun to see a random ooblet drifting somewhere you don't expect sometimes.

This game allows me to have fun without having to be a hardcore player.
Other games with the "relaxing" tag need to learn something from Ooblets. If I wanted to grind, I'd play Dark Souls.


On an ending note, the music is bomb.

review:
Collect all the ooblets!

Pro: I didn't feel like I needed a wiki to look up recipes and how to unlock stuff

Con: I wanted it to be a low-stress game, but I got too focused on getting every new ooblets every day, especially rare ones

Really enjoyed everything about this game until the level where you have to beat arcade games. I played ~50 hours on Switch, but pretty much gave up on that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043661162', 'num_games_owned': 674, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1600, 'last_played': 1702512595}
review:
I.Love.This.Game.
AND IT STILL GETS UPDATES.
I bought it originally on Epic Games and i have over 170h in that alone already. Its funny, its silly, its so much fun to chill with. Its not time bound or stressy. You can just do your thing. Your own house, your own farm, your own shop, decorate, customize, little outfits for your creatures, collecting... It has it all. I adore it and i am happy i got it and play it even still on Steam as well. To be fair, i never thought i'd like it as much as i did. Recommend.

review:
Ooblets ist ein sehr entspanntes Spiel bei dem die Stunden nur so dahin schmelzen.
Es gibt immer etwas zu tun wie Ressourcen sammeln, Produkte herstellen und mit Personen sprechen. Die Tanz-Duelle mit den Ooblets sind ein witziger Ansatz fÃ¼r ein gewaltloses KrÃ¤ftemessen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040595491', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1705274638}
review:
So far, it's my favorite game out of all cozy farming games. Especially quality of life features like saving whenever you want to or precise controls when working on your farm really sold this game for me.

Its systems are a bit more approachable compared to titles like Stardew Valley in a way that it makes mistakes much more forgiving. Still, that doesn't mean there isn't enough complexity and variety. There's always something to do that will keep me engaged. 

At first, I felt like the dance battles lacked in difficulty and I quickly became bored with them. However, the more you progress, they can become somewhat challenging. The different kinds of Ooblets with their variety in attacks really help to keep the battles fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561199198755266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8562, 'last_played': 1706856630}
review:
This game is stellar is you love animal crossing, stardew valley, harvest moon, pokemon etc.
 It's the perfect amount of grind with a fun card game system involving silly humor and dance parties. It's got replayability out the wazoo and it's a super cute and fun experience.
The only "problems" I'd say that I'd have with it is that it doesn't (hopefully yet) have modding capabilities. I've noticed a few bugs but It's mostly simple things that won't totally kill your game. Such as heads randomly shrinking on characters and if your wearing rollerskates you tend to get thrown behind furniture in your home.
In the end though easily at LEAST 9/10 do recommend! :D

review: I was skeptical during early access since I was so deep into ACNH at the time that I didn't really want to give this game a try. Steam sale this week and I figured I'd give it a shot... it's AMAZING. Great twist on cozy/farming games. I feel like after the popularity of ACNH we were flooded with "cozy" games that just never were as good because they never did anything different. This game does it. Worth it with a discount or full price imo.

author: {'steamid': '76561199080478830', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2084, 'last_played': 1706684608}
review: This is a really cute and derpy game with a mixture of farming, simple and easy dance battles with cards, and more! The sound effects are also worth noting because I've never heard anything like them in any game. Would def recommend this to someone who needs a simple game to play once in a while. It isn't demanding at all and easy to understand what you must do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198391986196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1700802953}

author: {'steamid': '76561198980307130', 'num_games_owned': 48, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 868, 'last_played': 1701148121}
review: I initially bought Ooblets when it first released on Epic Games back in 2020 and have loved the game from the very start. Getting to see how much it's grown since then has been amazing with the addition of new regions to visit, events to enjoy, and items to collect. It's always nice to see a game continue to receive such love in it's updates. Ooblets is a fairly simple game with an adorably quirky style that does a great job at combining the farming sim and creature collecting genres. Some may say it lacks depth but I really don't think it needs any extra depth, as it's meant to be a silly little game where you collect silly little creatures and make them have silly little dance battles with catchy music. That might not be everyone's cup of tea but to me it's perfect. I'm so excited to see it on Steam now because in my opinion it deserves as much attention and love as it can get! <3

author: {'steamid': '76561197983673342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1428, 'last_played': 1705022244}
review:
If you're looking for a game to relax with, you can't do better than Ooblets. Played best with a meditative attitude, Ooblets is a gentle farming sim with quicky characters and a really fun vibe. 
If you're looking for a super in-depth game with lots of deep characters and relationship building, this isn't the game for you - but if you're looking for something light to relax with after a hard day, I can't recommend Ooblets highly enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112684481', 'num_games_owned': 2100, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1294, 'last_played': 1706842406}
review:
"As someone that is still new to the gaming world, Ooblets was a great starter game for me. I started playing it during the Halloween event and loved all the decorations and spooky adventures I got to take my character on. I spend most of my time tending to my garden taking me back to my FarmVille days. Would highly recommend to the aesthetic girlies and pre-teens!" - BeautifulBoaz

As someone who falls into neither of the above categories, this game is fantastically whimsical and looks great. Runs like a champ on the SteamDeck, even on lower wattages. Would recommend to anyone who likes how the game looks, because it won't disappoint you with the gameplay underneath the pretty exterior.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995351187', 'num_games_owned': 832, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1256, 'last_played': 1707096852}
review:
This game is so goofy and fun.  The characters are so much fun, the sound design is incredible, and each little ooblet is adorable.  There's a lot to do in this game, and so many cute little critters to befriend.

Unlike pokemon, you actually respect the ooblets, and instead of combat you have dance battles because ooblets love dancing.  I have so much fun with this, and it works great on the steam deck as well (which is super cozy).

author: {'steamid': '76561199232202315', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1703766570}
review:
Ooblets, endlich! Ich hatte es mal auf der Switch angespielt und nun ist es endlich bei Steam! Ich bin im Suchtrausch. Diese Mischung aus Farmen, Pokemon mit Tanz und Questen neue Orte und es ist Cringe und Cozy! 

Wirklich einer der TOP Spiele fÃ¼r mich!

author: {'steamid': '76561199041818678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1700724167}
review: Ooblets is a game where you get lost in it's astounding visuals and monster collecting. Losing track of time by just the sheer fact that the music is awesome and the dance battles give collecting certain ooblets an essential part of the game! Overall, it's a great game and I highly recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198057104519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3547, 'last_played': 1700699748}
review:
Ooblets is a wonderful little experience where you get to collect cute friends. One of the best parts is they get to follow you around. 

It has a task system that makes sure you always have a goal to reach which makes it so the farming and gathering aspect doesn't get old. The goals are also actually attainable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198267491199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1572, 'last_played': 1704957853}
review:
I already knew this game would grant me at least 10 - 20 hours of fun, but it really has become my cozy game of the year. The time management aspect becomes only as hectic as you allow it to be, making for a fast paced farming/townie sim or a relaxed "one thing at a time" animal crossing-esque game. There are loads of different categories of things to be collected (for progression and just for fun) and the challenges asked of you are never too daunting. 

I feel no rush to get to the end of this game ASAP and know I will be coming back to it to see different holidays and seasonal events for at least another year or two. It is extremely accessible for all levels of gamers, works great with controller, m+k and steam deck and watching a silly little ooblet dance never fails to brighten my day :) Highly recommended!
